posts.title: Toddler Pillow Safety: When It's Safe (And When It's Not)
posts.description:
SO HERE'S THE THING: Your toddler's asking for a pillow now... but WHEN is it actually safe?

Most parents think 18 months, but there's actually more to it than that. I see this a lot in my practice ‚Äî families giving pillows way too early or stressing about it way too late.

Here's what the evidence shows us:
- Safe from 18 months, BUT your toddler still doesn't *need* one
- Many sleep better without until age 2 or 3
- What matters more? A firm, fitted mattress and NO loose blankets

Watch out for:
- Oversized pillows (should be kid-sized)
- Memory foam or super squishy pillows (suffocation risk)
- Pillows in the crib before 18 months (no debate)
- Adult-sized pillows in the toddler bed (not just uncomfortable, it's not safe)

If your toddler's asking, introduce a small, firm pillow designed for kids. But honestly? Most toddlers are fine without one until 2+. There's no rush, and that's okay.

Caption:
Toddler Pillows: When It's Safe (And When It's Not) üí§

When is it safe to introduce a pillow? 18 months is the magic number from a safety perspective, BUT ‚Äî and this is important ‚Äî your toddler doesn't actually NEED one yet.

The truth? Many toddlers sleep better, deeper, and more safely WITHOUT a pillow until age 2-3+. There's zero rush.

What matters way more:
‚ú® Firm, fitted mattress
‚ú® NO loose blankets, stuffed animals, or bumpers
‚ú® Just them + a fitted sheet in a safe sleep space

When you DO introduce a pillow:
‚úÖ Choose kid-sized (not adult)
‚úÖ Firm support, not squishy or memory foam
‚úÖ No pillows in the crib ‚Äî toddler bed only (18m+)
‚úÖ Make sure it's designed for little ones

Australian families: Check with your child health nurse if unsure ‚Äî they're amazing! ü§ç

So real question: Is your toddler demanding a pillow, or are they happy flat-headed and blissful? üòÑ Drop a comment!

posts.title: 5 Sleep Questions I Get Asked Every Single Week (Carousel - Option 1)
posts.description:
SLIDE 1 (Cover):
5 Sleep Questions I Get Asked EVERY Single Week
*By Jade, Hello Little Sleepers*

The same questions pop up constantly in my DMs.
Let's answer them together. ü§ç

---

SLIDE 2:
Q1: "Is my baby too young to have a sleep routine?"

Not even close.
Newborns can't DO a routine yet (their circadian rhythm isn't there).
BUT ‚Äî you can start micro-habits from day one:

‚Üí Same place for sleep
‚Üí Gentle dimming of lights as evening comes
‚Üí Consistency with how you respond

These aren't a "routine" yet. They're signal-setting.
By 6-8 weeks, you'll see these add up.

---

SLIDE 3:
Q2: "How do I know if it's a sleep regression or just bad habits forming?"

This stresses parents out SO much.

Regressions (normal):
- Last 2-4 weeks
- Often start suddenly
- Baby seems uncomfortable or needy
- Developmental leap happening (babbling, rolling, teething)

Bad habits forming:
- Weeks of the same pattern
- No developmental reason
- You've changed something
- It's become a reliance

Real talk? Most of what we call "bad habits" are actually regressions we're just noticing. Trust your gut. You know your baby.

---

SLIDE 4:
Q3: "Is it okay to let my baby cry? How much crying is too much?"

I don't do "cry it out" with families.
But I also don't say never let them cry.

Real-world balance:
- Can they cry while you're in the room? Yes.
- Can they cry while you're feeding them? Yes.
- Can they get upset? 100% ‚Äî they're learning something new.

What matters:
You're present. You're not abandoning them.
You're teaching them "you're safe, and sleep is what happens now."

The difference: Is baby crying with your support, or crying alone?
That's the line.

---

SLIDE 5:
Q4: "My toddler won't stay in bed. How do I know if it's a phase or a real problem?"

Toddlers testing boundaries = normal (so normal).
Toddler getting up 15+ times = worth looking at.

When it's likely just a phase:
- Started recently
- Happens once or twice per night
- Clearly testing what they can get away with
- They go back happily once guided

When it might need support:
- Going on for weeks
- Exhausting you + them
- Seems anxious (not naughty)
- Nothing obvious changed

If it's the second one? We can work on it.
You don't have to white-knuckle through forever.

---

SLIDE 6:
Q5: "Will co-sleeping ruin my baby's sleep independence?"

Short answer: No.
Long answer: It's more nuanced.

Co-sleeping can work beautifully IF:
- It's intentional (you chose it, not fell into it stressed)
- You have a plan for transitions when ready
- You're rested enough to handle it
- You want to do it

It gets harder IF:
- You're exhausted + resentful
- You have no transition plan
- Baby's waking constantly (co-sleep isn't solving the problem)
- Your partner is uncomfortable

Here's the thing: Babies co-sleeping with present, rested caregivers thrive.
Babies in rooms alone with stressed, resentful parents struggle.

The RELATIONSHIP matters more than the LOCATION.

---

SLIDE 7 (Closing):
Still have sleep questions? Send them my way. üí≠

DM me your burning sleep questions.
I answer them all.
(And your question might end up as the next carousel!)

posts.title: Monthly Sleep Guidelines by Age (Carousel)
posts.description:
SLIDE 1 (Cover):
What Does Healthy Sleep Look Like at YOUR Age?

Sleep needs change constantly.
And most parents have no idea what's normal.

Here's what healthy sleep looks like month by month. üìä

---

SLIDE 2:
NEWBORN (0-3 months)

Total Sleep Needed: 16-20 hours (scattered everywhere)

What's Normal:
‚Üí Sleeps in 2-4 hour stretches (broken, chaotic)
‚Üí No rhythm yet (sleeping at 3am, awake at noon is fine)
‚Üí Feeds drive sleep (eat, sleep, repeat)

Wake Windows: 45 min - 1.5 hours

Your Job:
ü§ç Safe sleep space (bassinet/cot, on back, no bumpers)
ü§ç Feed on demand (hungry babies can't sleep)
ü§ç Respond to cues (this is trust-building)
ü§ç Accept that this is chaos (it's temporary)

Real Talk: Expecting a 2-week-old to sleep through? That's biology talking, not laziness.

---

SLIDE 3:
4-6 MONTHS

Total Sleep Needed: 14-16 hours

What's Normal:
‚Üí Rhythm starting to emerge (yay!)
‚Üí 3-4 naps, plus nighttime
‚Üí Longer stretches at night (maybe 4-6 hours)
‚Üí Daytime sleep gets more predictable

Wake Windows: 1.5 - 2 hours

What to Watch:
‚Üí First potential sleep regression (4-month sleep regression is REAL)
‚Üí Development explosion (rolling, grabbing, more alert)
‚Üí Some babies sleep better, some get worse

Your Job:
ü§ç Start noticing a rhythm (loose routine is helpful)
ü§ç Protect nap times
ü§ç Night sleep will still have wakings (normal)
ü§ç Trust the patterns that emerge

---

SLIDE 4:
6-9 MONTHS

Total Sleep Needed: 14-16 hours

What's Normal:
‚Üí 2-3 naps (morning + afternoon + sometimes a catnap)
‚Üí Longer night sleep (6-8 hours possible)
‚Üí More clear wake windows
‚Üí Still waking at night (not unusual)

Wake Windows: 2 - 2.5 hours

Developmental Stuff:
‚Üí Stranger anxiety (they might resist naps with caregivers)
‚Üí Learning to sit up (sudden motion in sleep)
‚Üí Sleep regression possible around 8 months

Your Job:
ü§ç Protect a clear routine
ü§ç Nap times matter (don't skip to "tire them out")
ü§ç Night wakings are still normal
ü§ç They can stay in their own room (or yours, your call)

---

SLIDE 5:
9-12 MONTHS

Total Sleep Needed: 12-16 hours

What's Normal:
‚Üí 2 naps (usually, sometimes still 3)
‚Üí Night sleep around 8-12 hours
‚Üí Some babies sleeping through, some not
‚Üí Early wakings common (6am is "normal")

Wake Windows: 2.5 - 3 hours

Big Changes:
‚Üí Separation anxiety peaks (they NEED you)
‚Üí Crawling/cruising (affecting sleep comfort)
‚Üí Teething possibilities
‚Üí Sleep regression around 9 months

Your Job:
ü§ç Reassurance is still okay (respond to their needs)
ü§ç Consistency + routine = security
ü§ç Night wakings may increase (normal)
ü§ç Don't fight the early mornings yet (it passes)

---

SLIDE 6:
1-2 YEARS (Toddler!)

Total Sleep Needed: 11-14 hours

What's Normal:
‚Üí 1-2 naps (usually 1 strong afternoon nap + maybe a morning one)
‚Üí 10-12 hours night sleep
‚Üí Some sleeping through, some still waking
‚Üí Early wake times (6-7am is normal)
‚Üí Resistance to naps/bedtime (testing boundaries)

Wake Windows: 3 - 4 hours

The Reality:
‚Üí They WILL fight sleep (it's developmental)
‚Üí They WILL test you (every single bedtime)
‚Üí Naps get harder to protect
‚Üí Night wakings still normal (teething, separation, regressions)

Your Job:
ü§ç Firm, kind boundaries (bedtime is non-negotiable)
ü§ç Routine is your best friend
ü§ç Consistency matters MORE than you think
ü§ç Some fighting is normal ‚Äî consistency wins

---

SLIDE 7:
2-3 YEARS (Big Toddler)

Total Sleep Needed: 11-13 hours

What's Normal:
‚Üí 1 solid nap (30 min - 2 hours, both normal)
‚Üí 10-12 hours night sleep
‚Üí Strong preference for nighttime (bedtime battles decrease)
‚Üí Some skip naps, some fight them
‚Üí Sleeping through night gets more consistent

Wake Windows: 4 - 5.5 hours

The Shifts:
‚Üí Logic developing (can explain/negotiate)
‚Üí Independence increasing (fighting control)
‚Üí Better language (can express needs)
‚Üí More consistent night sleep possible

Your Job:
ü§ç Nap transitions starting (respect if they're not tired)
ü§ç Bedtime can be earlier now (less fighting)
ü§ç They can understand explanations
ü§ç Boundaries still firm, but reasoning helps

---

SLIDE 8 (Closing):
REMEMBER:

‚ú® These are guidelines, not gospel
‚ú® Every child is different (your baby isn't broken)
‚ú® Regressions happen (they pass)
‚ú® Consistency matters more than method
‚ú® Your instincts + the science = your answer

Not sleeping? Not alone. Not broken. Just learning. üíô

posts.title: A Real 18-Month Sleep Schedule (Not A Rule, Just An Example)
posts.description:
A Real 18-Month Sleep Schedule (Not A Rule, Just An Example) üí§

Someone asked what a "good" sleep schedule looks like.

Here's an example of what worked for a lot of families ‚Äî but here's the important part: This is ONE example, not the rule.

Your toddler's schedule might look totally different. And that's okay.

---

18-MONTH SAMPLE SCHEDULE:

6:30am ‚Äî Wake up (maybe earlier, maybe later)
7:00am ‚Äî Breakfast + milk
8:00-9:00am ‚Äî Wake window, playtime/outing
9:00-9:30am ‚Äî Optional second nap (some kids still have this, some don't)
9:30am ‚Äî Wake, snack
10:00am-12:30pm ‚Äî Wake window, activity/park/playtime
12:30pm ‚Äî Lunch
1:00-3:00pm ‚Äî Nap time (the main event)
3:00pm ‚Äî Wake, snack
3:15-5:30pm ‚Äî Wake window, playtime/activity
5:30pm ‚Äî Dinner / wind down begins
6:00pm ‚Äî Bath time
6:15pm ‚Äî Wind down routine (pyjamas, cuddles, books)
6:30-7:00pm ‚Äî Bedtime
6:30pm-7:00am ‚Äî Sleep

---

WHAT THIS ISN'T:

‚ùå Not perfect (some days are chaos)
‚ùå Not for everyone (every kid's different)
‚ùå Not a rule you have to follow
‚ùå Not what works if your toddler is different

---

WHY THIS WORKS (For Some):

‚úÖ Wake windows match 18-month needs (3-4 hours)
‚úÖ One strong nap is protected
‚úÖ Bedtime is early-ish (prevents overtired)
‚úÖ Rhythm is consistent (nervous system likes this)
‚úÖ Realistic (includes real life)

---

WHY IT MIGHT NOT WORK FOR YOU:

Your toddler might:
‚Üí Sleep through the 9:30am cat nap (skip it!)
‚Üí Be down to 30-min naps (still counts as nap)
‚Üí Go to bed at 7:30 instead of 6:30 (if night sleep is protected)
‚Üí Be in daycare (rhythm is what it is)
‚Üí Have different hunger patterns (that's okay)

---

THE ACTUAL RULE:

There's only one: Consistency matters more than timing.

Whether your 18-month-old naps at 1pm or 2pm matters less than them napping at 1pm (or 2pm) every single day.

Your body clock doesn't care what time it is. It cares about the pattern.

---

What does YOUR 18-month-old's schedule look like?

Drop it in the comments. Let's see the variety! ü§ç

(And if yours looks nothing like this ‚Äî that's not a problem. It's just different.)

#ToddlerSchedule #SleepSchedule #18Months #ToddlerParenting #HelloLittleSleepers #RealParenting #GentleSleep

posts.title: Weekly Newsletter: The Thing Everyone Gets Wrong About Toddler Sleep
posts.description:
Subject: The thing everyone gets wrong about toddler sleep (and why it matters) ü§ç

---

Hi friends,

I got three DMs this week asking the same question.

"Is my toddler doing this right?"

And here's what struck me: None of them trusted their instincts. All of them thought something was wrong. All of them were exhausted.

Sound familiar?

---

Here's what they all had in common:

They were waiting for their toddler to "obviously look tired" before bedtime.

Which meant they'd already missed the window.

Which meant a 2-hour bedtime battle.

Which meant a wired toddler at 8pm.

Which meant they went to bed thinking they'd failed.

They hadn't. They'd just bought the myth.

---

The myth is this:

"Tired babies sleep better."

It's everywhere. It makes intuitive sense. So you do all the things to tire them out.

More playdates. Longer outings. Extra stimulation. Hoping they'll crash.

And sometimes they do. But most of the time? They get overtired.

And overtired toddlers don't sleep. They fight. They melt down. They wake constantly.

The truth is the opposite:

Toddlers sleep BEST when you catch them *before* they're obviously tired.

---

This week's content:

We're diving into all of this.

‚ú® Monday: Pillow safety (because your toddler's probably asking)
‚ú® Tuesday: Common sleep questions (straight from parent DMs)
‚ú® Wednesday: Why Hello Little Sleepers exists (Harvey's turning 2!)
‚ú® Thursday: Sleep myths you probably believe
‚ú® Friday: What healthy sleep looks like at every age
‚ú® Saturday: Real 18-month schedule example (not a rule, just real life)

---

What you can do right now:

1. Check your wake windows
Know your toddler's age? Look up the wake window. Then check ‚Äî are you respecting it, or have bedtime been drifting?

2. Try one earlier bedtime
Even 15 minutes earlier can change everything. Give it a week. See what happens.

3. Stop waiting for "obvious tired signs"
Watch for: Rubbing eyes, zoning out, getting a bit clingy. Those are the signs. Not the melting down.

---

You're doing better than you think.

And if sleep is still hard? You don't have to white-knuckle through it alone.

That's what I'm here for. üíô

Drop me a reply if you have burning sleep questions.

‚Äî Jade

P.S. ‚Äî Harvey's turning 2 this week. If you follow on Instagram, there's a real post coming about motherhood, exhaustion, and why I do this work. You might relate.

posts.title: Why Some Families Sleep Better (Soft Sell Reel - Sunday Option 2)
posts.hook: Here's the one thing all the families who sleep well have in common... and it's not what you think.

SCRIPT:
[0-3 SEC] HOOK: Direct, curious. 'Here's the one thing all the families who sleep well have in common... And it's not what you think.'

[3-12 SEC] COMMON ASSUMPTION: Animated. 'You probably think: They have an easy baby. They're naturally good at parenting. They got lucky. They have more patience. None of that is true.'

[12-25 SEC] ACTUAL DIFFERENCE: Speaking clearly, authoritative. 'The difference is this: They got SUPPORT. Not because they're special. Not because they have it all figured out. But because they recognized sleep was hard and decided to do something about it.'

[25-35 SEC] WHAT THAT LOOKS LIKE: Leaning forward. 'That might look like: Reading a guide | Asking a friend | Getting professional support | Trying a different approach. It's not genius. It's just... asking for help.'

[35-43 SEC] THE TRUTH: More vulnerable. 'You know what the difference is? Struggling families think they should know this automatically. They suffer in silence. Families that sleep well? They decided sleep was worth figuring out.'

[43-45 SEC] CTA: Warm, inviting. 'If sleep's hard, you don't have to figure it out alone. üíô'

CAPTION:
Why Some Families Sleep Better (It's Not What You Think) ü§ç

You probably assume families with great sleepers:
- Got lucky with an easy baby
- Are naturally patient
- Have it all figured out
- Never struggle

Wrong.

The actual difference? They got support.

Not because they're special. Not because they have some secret. But because they decided sleep was worth investing in.

What support looks like: Reading a book | Asking a friend | Getting guidance | Trying a different approach. It's not complicated. It's just intentional.

Here's the difference I see:

Families that struggle: Think they should know this instinctively | Feel ashamed asking | Try to white-knuckle | Normalize exhaustion | Suffer in silence

Families that figure it out: Know sleep is learnable | Ask for support | Get tailored guidance | Actually sleep

You don't have a broken kid. You just have a kid who hasn't slept well yet. And that's fixable.

It's about understanding what your kid ACTUALLY needs, then doing the work. Which most parents can do. But you usually need someone to show you how.

If sleep's been hard, you're not alone. üíô

[0-3 SEC] HOOK: Leaning in, intimate. 'The thing parents tell me most after their sleep improves... It's never actually about the sleep.'

[3-12 SEC] WHAT THEY SAY: Quoting, warm. 'They say: I feel like myself again. I didn't realize how exhausted I was. My relationship improved. I have patience for my kid again.'

[12-23 SEC] DEEPER TRUTH: Sitting back. 'The sleep getting better? That's the side effect. What actually changes is their LIFE. Because sleep isn't just about sleep. It's about having enough in the tank to be present. To be patient. To be the parent you want to be.'

[23-35 SEC] THE REALIZATION: More animated. 'Parents realize: They weren't failing, just exhausted | The behavior problems were overtired signals | They could enjoy parenting when rested | Their whole family got calmer.'

[35-45 SEC] THE HOPE: Warm, direct. 'And here's what gets me: Nobody sets out to be an exhausted, resentful parent. We all start wanting to ENJOY this. And when sleep improves? That joy comes back.'

What Parents Say After Things Change üíô

The most beautiful part of my job isn't when babies start sleeping well. It's when PARENTS tell me: 'I feel like myself again.'

Before support: Exhausted constantly | Resentful | Snapping at everyone | Feeling like a failure | Wondering if you made a mistake

After things improve: You sleep better | You have capacity | Patience returns | You actually ENJOY your kid | You remember why you wanted this

Here's what parents actually say: 'I didn't realize how exhausted I was until I wasn't anymore.' 'My partner and I are actually kind to each other again.' 'Parenting is actually enjoyable now.' 'I feel like a person, not just a survival robot.'

This isn't about being a good parent. It's about having enough REST to show up as yourself.

An exhausted parent can't be patient. That's biology. And the fix? Actually fixable.

So if you're in it right now: If parenting doesn't feel joyful | If you're exhausted | If you're wondering if you made a mistake

You probably haven't. You're just tired. And that changes when sleep changes.
